original_data.question: A previously healthy 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden weakness of her right arm and leg that started 3 hours ago. She returned from a business trip from Europe 3 days ago. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 115/min and regular, and blood pressure is 155/85 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased muscle strength on the entire right side. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ on the right. Babinski sign is present on the right. The left lower leg is swollen, erythematous, and tender to palpation. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

model_response:
This patient's findings suggest a left-sided cerebrovascular accident (CVA) with a right hemiparesis and a left leg deep venous thrombosis (DVT). The DVT is a consequence of the CVA. The patient most likely has a patent foramen ovale (PFO), which can allow a thrombus from the deep venous system of the leg to pass into the arterial system and the brain. Women who use oral contraceptives are at increased risk for DVT. Cigarette smoking also increases the risk for DVT. Mitral valve vegetations would be expected to produce a left-sided heart murmur. Atrial fibrillation would be expected to produce an irregular pulse. Carotid artery dissection would be expected to produce a Horner syndrome.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Having no significant health-related issues.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
Clinical sign or symptom manifested as debility, or lack or loss of strength and energy.
The region of the lower limb in animals, extending from the gluteal region to the FOOT, and including the BUTTOCKS; HIP; and LEG.
Any formal business entity for profit, which may be a corporation, a partnership, association or individual proprietorship.
The continent north of AFRICA, west of ASIA and east of the ATLANTIC OCEAN.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
Roll of dried and finely cut TOBACCO leaves wrapped in a cylinder of thin paper used for SMOKING.
Occurring or done each day.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
The oval-shaped oral cavity located at the apex of the digestive tract and consisting of two parts: the vestibule and the oral cavity proper.
Chemical substances that prevent or reduce the probability of CONCEPTION.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
Customary, usual, or at fixed intervals; conforming to a standard or pattern.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A subjective response indicating that something is or has decreased.

The amount of force generated by MUSCLE CONTRACTION. Muscle strength can be measured during isometric, isotonic, or isokinetic contraction, either manually or using a device such as a MUSCLE STRENGTH DYNAMOMETER.
Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.

Contraction of a muscle triggered by a signal from a muscle spindle in response to a stimulus applied to a specific trigger point on the body. The strength of the response can provide insight into central and peripheral nerve performance.
